description: From Latin exhilarāre (“to delight, to gladden, to make merry”), from ex- (“out, away”) (from Proto-Indo-European *h₁eǵʰs (“out”)) + hilarāre, present infinitive of hilarō (“to cheer, to gladden”), from hilaris (“cheerful, light-hearted, lively”), from Ancient Greek ἱλαρός (hilarós, “cheerful, merry”), from ἵλαος (hílaos, “gracious, kind, propitious”), from Proto-Indo-European *selh₂- (“comfort, mercy”).

verbs.description: exhilarate (third-person singular simple present exhilarates, present participle exhilarating, simple past and past participle exhilarated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cheer, to cheer up, to gladden, to make happy.
examples: Good news exhilarates the mind; wine exhilarates the drinker.
Harriet became suddenly conscious that every woman in the room was gazing furtively or with frank interest at Wimsey and herself, and the knowledge exhilarated her.
